xxl.core.io.converters
Class ConvertableConverter<T extends Convertable>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.io.converters.Converter<T>
      xxl.core.io.converters.ConvertableConverter<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the object that can be converted by using this converter (must be a subtype of Convertable).
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class ConvertableConverter<T extends Convertable>
extends Converter<T>

This class provides a converter that is able to read and write objects that implements the Convertable interface. The objects are read and written by calling their read and write methods. When reading an object a factory method can be used for creating the object instead of specifying it.

Example usage (1). 

   // create a byte array output stream
   
   ByteArrayOutputStream output = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
   
   // create two convertable objects (bit sets)
   
   BitSet b1 = new BitSet(13572l);
   BitSet b2 = new BitSet(-1l);
   
   // create a factory method for bit sets
   
   Function<Object, BitSet> factory = new Function<Object, BitSet>() {
       public BitSet invoke() {
           return new BitSet();
       }
   };
   
   // create a new convertable converter that converts bit sets
   
   ConvertableConverter<BitSet> converter = new ConvertableConverter<BitSet>(factory);
   
   // write the bit sets to the output stream
   
   converter.write(new DataOutputStream(output), b1);
   converter.write(new DataOutputStream(output), b2);
   
   // create a byte array input stream on the output stream
   
   ByteArrayInputStream input = new ByteArrayInputStream(output.toByteArray());
   
   // read the bit sets from the input stream and compare it to
   // the original bit sets
   
   System.out.println(b1.compareTo(converter.read(new DataInputStream(input))));
   System.out.println(b2.compareTo(converter.read(new DataInputStream(input))));
   
   // close the streams after use
   
   input.close();
   output.close();

See Also:
DataInput, DataOutput, Function, IOException, Serialized Form

Field Detail

DEFAULT_INSTANCE

public static final ConvertableConverter<Convertable> DEFAULT_INSTANCE
This instance can be used for getting a default instance of a convertable converter. It is similar to the Singleton Design Pattern (for further details see Creational Patterns, Prototype in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides) except that there are no mechanisms to avoid the creation of other instances of a convertable converter.

function

protected Function<?,? extends T extends Convertable> function
A factory method that is used for initializing the object to read. This function will be invoked when the read method is called without specifying an object to restore.

Constructor Detail

ConvertableConverter

public ConvertableConverter(Function<?,? extends T> function)
Constructs a new convertable converter and uses the specified function as factory method. For this reason the object to read must not be specified when calling the read method. In this case the object is initialized be invoking the specified function.

Parameters:
function - a factory method that is used for initializinge the object to read when it is not specified.

ConvertableConverter

public ConvertableConverter()
Constructs a new convertable converter without a factory method. For this reason the objects to read must be explicitly specified when calling the read method.

Method Detail

read

public T read(DataInput dataInput,
              T object)
                           throws IOException
Reads the state (the attributes) for the specified object from the specified data input and returns the restored object.

This implementation uses the specified object (that implements the convertable interface) to call its read method. When this object is null it is initialized by invoking the function (factory method).

Specified by:
read in class Converter<T extends Convertable>
Parameters:
dataInput - the stream to read data from in order to restore the object.
object - the object to be restored. If the object is null it is initialized by invoking the function (factory method).
Returns:
the restored object.
Throws:
IOException - if I/O errors occur.
NullPointerException - when the given object is null and no factory method is specified.

write

public void write(DataOutput dataOutput,
                  T object)
           throws IOException
Writes the state (the attributes) of the specified object to the specified data output.

This implementation calls the write method of the specified object (that implements the convertable interface).

Specified by:
write in class Converter<T extends Convertable>
Parameters:
dataOutput - the stream to write the state (the attributes) of the object to.
object - the object whose state (attributes) should be written to the data output.
Throws:
IOException - includes any I/O exceptions that may occur.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
                 throws IOException
The main method contains some examples how to use a convertable converter. It can also be used to test the functionality of a convertable converter.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
Throws:
IOException - includes any I/O exceptions that may occur.
